entry.et: Latin Angli, plural, of Germanic origin; akin to Old English Engle Angles

def.dt: :a member of a Germanic people that invaded England along with the Saxons and Jutes in the fifth century a.d. and merged with them to form the Anglo-Saxon peoples

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin angulus

def.dt: :a corner whether constituting a projecting part or a partially enclosed space they sheltered in an angle of the building
:the figure formed by two lines extending from the same point
:dihedral angle
:a measure of an angle or of the amount of turning necessary to bring one line or plane into coincidence with or parallel to another
:the precise viewpoint from which something is observed or considered a camera angle consider the question from all angles
:the aspect seen from such an angle discuss all angles of the question
:a special approach, point of attack, or technique for accomplishing an objective try a new angle
:an often improper or illicit method of obtaining advantage a salesman always looking for an angle
:a sharply divergent course the road went off at an angle
:a position to the side of an opponent in football from which a player may block his opponent more effectively or without penalty usually used in the phrases get an angle or have an angle
:to turn or proceed at an angle
:to turn, move, or direct at an angle
:to present (as a news story) from a particular or prejudiced point of view :slant

entry.et: Middle English angelen, from angel fishhook, from Old English, from anga hook; akin to Old High German ango hook, Latin uncus, Greek onkos barbed hook, ankos glen

def.dt: :to fish with a hook
:to use artful means to attain an objective angled for an invitation
:bracket 3b
:an iron cleat for joining parts of a structure at an angle
:a piece of structural steel rolled with an L-shaped section
:the acute angle between the direction of the relative wind and the chord of an airfoil
:the angle formed by the line of sight and the horizontal plane for an object below the horizontal
:the angle formed by the line of sight and the horizontal plane for an object above the horizontal
:the angle that a line (as a ray of light) falling on a surface or interface makes with the normal drawn at the point of incidence
